conclusion: Analyze the motion of the basketball before and after the collision with the ground, considering air resistance.
Determine the velocities before and after the collision.
Before the collision: The basketball is dropped from height H and experiences gravity and air resistance.
Equation of motion for the basketball as it falls: m dv/dt = -mg - λmg = -mg(1 + λ).
Integrating from v = 0 at t = 0 to v = v1 at t = t1 gives v1 = -g(1 + λ)t1.
Using kinematic equation for distance: H = -1/2 g(1 + λ)t1^2.
Solving for t1: t1 = sqrt(2H / g(1 + λ)).
Velocity just before the collision: v1 = -sqrt(2gH(1 + λ)).
After the collision: The basketball rebounds to height h.
Equation of motion for the basketball as it rises: m dv/dt = -mg + λmg = -mg(1 - λ).
Integrating from v = v2 at t = 0 to v = 0 at t = t2 gives v2 = g(1 - λ)t2.
Using kinematic equation for distance: h = 1/2 g(1 - λ)t2^2.
Solving for t2: t2 = sqrt(2h / g(1 - λ)).
Velocity just after the collision: v2 = sqrt(2gh(1 - λ)).
Determine the ratio of the post-collision velocity to the pre-collision velocity.
Ratio of post-collision to pre-collision velocity: v2/|v1| = sqrt(h(1 - λ) / H(1 + λ)).
Final answer: The ratio is sqrt(h(1 - λ) / H(1 + λ)).
